SOPHS AND FROSH
BATTLE TO TIE
Listless Battle Marked by Frequent Fumbles

Freshman hopes of making a
Clean sweep in all lower class competitions were dashed to the ground
.when a belated rally late in the
fourth quarter ended in a fumble on
the Sophs' 10-yard line. Previous
to this long march into the opposing territory, the Frosh had been
unable to gain little against the
heavier and more experienced line
of the Sophs.
First Half Even

The first half was characterized
by typically Frosh-Soph poor football. Little life was shown by either
team and no science whatsoever.
Whatever advantage there was lay
on the side of the Sophomores, who
Were able to make fewer fumbles,
and as a result a better showing.
For the entire first half the play
see-sawed back and forth around
the middle fo the field, neither team
having a capable attack to cope with
the strong defensive skill exhibited.
Frosh Fumble

The Frosh were particularly unfortunate in that they contintually
fumbled, Gibson, their only threat,
being especially guilty of this. A
long run around the end would get
Well underway and the white markers would be passing swiftly underfoot when a Soph would tackle and
the ball fly, only to be recovered
by the opposition. These fumbles
really cost the Frosh the game, for
Otherwise they outplayed their natural enemies and showed a far
greater knowledge of the game.
Sophs Lack Preparation

The lack of preparation for the
struggle was clearly -shown by the
Sophs, in their inability to throw
Passes or work in co-ordination in
any of their plays. The one high
spot of the game was the clean
tackling done by both teams, a very
unusual sight heretofore in the annual underclassmen's battles. Gump
for the Sophs was particularly effective in his defensive work.

Botanist to Lecture
On Central America
Using as his subject, "A Talk on
Central America," Mr. P. R. White,
who is pursuing a course in botany
at Johns Hopkins, will deliver an
address today.
The lecture, which will be supplemented by illustrations, will be
based on the lecturer's own experience. Mr. White, during the past
tWO years, has visited Cuba, Jamaica, Costa Rica and Panama.

PRICE 5 CENTS

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 6, 1927

CONTRACT LET FOR
WELCH LIBRARY
The contract for the erection of the William H Welch
Medical Library at the Johns
Hopkins Medical School has
been let to the Consolidated
Engineering Company, the
lowest bidder. It is expected
that, work will be begun immediately. Plans are being
made to have it completed
within ten months. The
structure itself will cost about
$397,000 and the total cost of
the building equipped will be
between $600,000 and $700,000.

TO REPLACE
SWIMMING AS WINTER SPORT

KELLY TO CAPTAIN
BASKETBALL
JAY HARRIERS

Wheeler, Track Star,
Patents Invention

Robert Kelly was elected captain of the 1928 Johns Hopkins
cross-country team at a meeting
held last Thursday night. Kelly
was opposed by Wheeler, but received a majority of votes for the
office.
• Kelly has been running very well
this season, placing close to Gwinn
and Schiebel in every race. He
placed third in the Maryland contest and showed well in the National
Junior A. A. U. meet on November
11. Kelly succeeds Herman Schiebel as captain of the Jay crosscountry squad.

Harold A. Wheeler, a graduate
student in the department of mathematics, has recently invented and
patented an automatic volume control for radio receivers that will
eliminate to some extent the fading
of distant stations.
The inventor of this device
claims that if incorporated in the
amplifying section of a receiver,
the operator will be enabled to tune
in on station after station without
any change in volume.
He said that the carrier wave of
the station is amplified and then rectified, the wave being used to control volume by applying a varying
negative voltage to the grid of the
adio frequency amplifier.
Wheeler is better known to Hopkins students as a member of the
cross-country team, which has just
closed one of the most successful
seasons in the history of Hopkins
track, and for his sterling work in
the half-mile on last spring's squad.

Hopkins will enter a team in the
South Atlantic Amateur Athletic
Union meet to be held on December 17 at Clifton Park. Gwinn,
Schiebel and Kelly will run for
Hopkins and four other men will be
picked from Wheeler, Emerson,
Water,_Rosser, Yellott, Miller and
Onorato to enter with them.
The course will be the same as
that traversed by the Blue Jays in
the National Junior A. A. U. meet
held on November 11. The course
is two miles long and will be covered three times by the contestants.
The starting and finishing line will
be the Mansion House in Clifton
Park.
The Emorywood Athletic Club
has already signified its intention of
entering the race and this will proyide another opportunity for a meeting between Bill Agee and Dick
Gwinn. Agee has beaten Gwinn
twice by a small margin and this
meet will give the Hopkins runner
an attempt to avenge these defeats.

ENGINEERS' DANCE
SATURDAY NIGHT
This Saturday evening, December 10, the annual Engineers' dance will be held in the
C. E. Hall. Though given by
the members of the Engineering School, the whole student
body is invited, and it is hoped
that a large crowd will turn
out.
The admission will be one
dollar stag or couple; tickets
may be obtained from the
committee — John Mathews,
John Eldridge and Ferd Kaufholz.

To Enter A. A. U. Meet

FROSH AND SOPHS TOSS PAINT
BUT RUSH ENDS IN USUAL!TIE
The usual draw concluded what
was literally one of the most colorful gatherings of the season. Purnell Hall's sophomores and Martin
Eliot's frosh had at each other Saturday afternoon in the accepted
manner, with innovations. The
innovations in this year's class rush
were, of course, the substitution of
one period for two, and of freeflowing red and green paint for a
torn flag mounted by a boy.
This departure from former practice was intended to end the hopeless series of ties in which the rushes
have frequently finished, but its
purpose seems not 'to have been
carried. Any attempt to assign a
name to the color of the pole at the
end of the fray would have been
overly. ambitious, and Judge Blandi
perforce followed the only course
open to him in pronouncing the result a draw.
The pep meeting of the freshmen was a complete failure as such,
but it served to assemble the vanguard of thirty-one's rough-clad
warriors, who laid plans for distressing the poor sophs.
Many outsiders were among the
rather large crowd which gathered
on the hill at the east end of the
main field and below on the edge of
the practice field. The cold, brisk
weather put a snap in the spectators
and made them wish for action.
The gallery was largely composed
of upperclassmen, some "dragging,"
but mostly alone. The ultra-collegiate element was represented by
the sprinkling of canes and fur

coats, not to mention the almost
omnipresent derby. Older men and
even gray-haired women were not
wanting among the onlookers.
But the greatest color—disregarding that supplied in liquid form
—was offered by the combatants
themselves. Dressed in slickers,
overalls, sweaters, sweat-shirts.
khaki shirts and trousers, R. O. T.
C. shirts, held together with book
straps, their heads covered in old
hats, caps, bathing caps—particularly blue bathing caps—their eyes
shielded by goggles, their hands protected by red rubber gloves, the
opposing classmen met.
The first clash came as a surprise
and centered not around the gaunt
green pole, but a Tudor Ford sedan
some 50 yards distant. •Just what
the result was nobody knows, but
a great deal of ripe fruit and overripe hen fruit was sprinkled about,
to the accompaniment of a fire extinguisher in action, which got beyond the control of its operator and
threatened to disrupt the whole
works.
A few seconds later the real war
started, with the spphomores nobly
defending their post from the onslaught of the freshmen. The battle was joined with more casting of
groceries and was closely followed
by the frantic application of red and
then green paint brushes in confusing succession. A long, sweeping
red stroke! And then a green one
on- top of it. Or an energetic sophomore seeking to eradicate the red
with his hands or his clothing. But

TAU BETA P110 INITIATE FIVE MEN
Dean Whitehead of Engineering
School to be Principal
Speaker at Assembly
Four seniors and one junior will
be initiated into Tau Beta Pi, honorary engineering fraternity, at this
Thursday's assembly. Dean Whitehead of the Engineering School,
who has recently returned from his
tour of Europe as Exchange Professor to France, will be the speaker of the occasion. He will comment on his trip.
Initiations into Tau Beta Pi are
held twice each year, in the spring
and fall. In the fall the upperquarter of the senior class and three
of the upper eight of the junior
class are eligible for election. In
the spring only the upper eight of
the junior class are eligible. Scholarship is the primary requirement
to admission, but other qualifications are also taken into consideration. Tau Beta Pi is rated a5 high
in engineering circles as is Phi Beta
Kappa for academic scholarship.
The names of the five new Hopkins
initiates are being withheld until
the assembly.

BOOKS

TWO YEARS OR FOUR
An interesting sequel to Mr. George H. Palmer's polemic
against the junior college in last April's Atlantic Monthly appears
in the current number of the Atlantic. Mr. Palmer's arguments
are based upon two assumptions: that the American colleges are
instrumental in creating a class of men whom we might term
the "gifted amateur," and that "in life everywhere it is the 'over
and above' that counts."
The junior college should not be regarded, it seems to us, as a
sort of preparatory school for two more years of cultural education. If its function were this, it would be an undeniable
anomaly. If a man feels that he needs or wants four years of
cultural preparation, he should attend a college for four years,
but should not take two years at a junior college and then two
more at a college.
The problem, however, is not, as Mr. Palmer says, the segregation of the "competent" from the "incompetent" by sending the
latter to junior college, but a determination, if possible, of whether
or not the great majority of men who do spend four years at
college would not have done just as well if they had attended only
two years. Palmer continues to say that the only fit judges of
who are "competent" and who are not are the candidates themselves. This is only partially true, for the real test of whether
or not a college education has been a benefit comes after a man
has been out of college for four or five years. It is only then
that he can tell whether his "liberal education" has opened to him
new channels of thought, new channels of reading, and newer
interests in life which would have remained closed to him had
he not attended college.
Though thefe is, of course, no definite proof of the value of a
four-year course as opposed to a two-year course, we are inclined
to believe that the very great majority of college men's lives would
be practically the same had they received two years of collegiate
education or four. The "gifted amateur," if he be truly gifted,
will interest himself in his hobby just as much after two years
as he would after four. There may be a few exceptions, but they
are not in the majority. And those men in whom their college
years have not excited additional intellectual curiosity certainly
gain nothing from the additional two years.
In advocating the junior college, we assume that it should be
conducted along collegiate, and not prep school lines. It would
then fulfill the needs of the very great majority of men who are
now spending four years in getting a "background" which they
could obtain in less. And those men who really, sincerely feel
that they want more than merely a background can study for
higher degrees.

FIGURES IN RELIGIOUS CENSUS INDICATE
LIBERALITY IN RELIGOUS THOUGHT
Figures of the annual religious
census, taken among the undergraduates by the campus Young Men's
Christian Association, show a
marked increase in the number of
men who declare no preference for
any particular church denomination.
Of a total of 770 students represented in the census, 144, or a little
les sthan 19 per cent., show no preference. Last year's percentage of
these students was about 14 per
cent., while reports of previous years
also show a steady upward increase.
Commenting,upon this phase of
the census results, E. A. Schaal,
intercollegiate secretary of the Hopkins "Y," expressed the opinion that
the facts show a tendency toward
liberality in religious thought.
"It may be," Mr. Schaal said,
"that the increase is a reflection of
the public attitude, toward the
church. For I believe that college
students are a representative crosssection of the community.
Attitude Shifting

"Apparently, the public attitude
is shifting—becoming negative with
regard to religious matters. There
is in progress a revolt against the

Apparently George had that inJ. L. S.
definable something which made
him irresistible to sex starved women. It is estimated that he had
affairs with at least thirty and probably many more women. Of this
number he married about twentyone. However, George was never
arrested for polygamy. In fact,
after deserting and robbing his girl
friends, he was still their ideal and
was welcome to return to them
whenever he chose. George was
far from being handsome, as could
be readily determined from a picture which Dr. Oliver exhibited to
the residents.
For a while he was happy and
contented with merely leaving after
one of his honeymoons with his
wife's clothes and ready cash, but
having mastered this game he became ambitious and desired to do
bigger and better things. In order
to obtain the entire estate of his
wife, he found that it would be
necessary to have her sign it over
to him and then dispose of her.
After treating his new wife to an
enjoyable honeymoon and having
her sign her estate over to him,
George suggested that she take a
bath. During the bath he grabbed
her by a leg with one hand and
shoved her head down with the
other. A few tears and George took
over the estate. Finally, one of
his father-in-laws checked up on
him and one beautiful day they attached a rope to his neck.
Many interesting and curious details were brought out during his
trial, which lasted twenty-four days.
It was a subject of much interest
as to the cause of George's strange
influence over women. Furthermore, the technique of the murder
itself was carefully studied and
enacted in the court. Few criminals
are original, but George contributed
a novel method of disposal to the
criminal records.
The trial brought out that even
George had several admirable traits.
In spite of his many affaires du
caeur, he remained faithful to one
woman to whom he always returned
after one of his exploits. He gave
her some of the clothes that he had
robbed from his wives. He posed
as an antique collector and explained his sudden wealth by a,fortunate sale of some piece of pottery
or the like. Furthermore, George
always showed his wives a good
time before he murdered them. Divorce never bothered George.
In closing, Dr. Oliver expressed
the wish that no resident possesses

nitely- chosen and if anyone feels

This is the golden opportunity for
our women—will they show enough
interest in the movement to bring
it to a successful completion, or
will they let others usurp the place
in sports that is rightfully ours?
The decision is for them to make—
may they choose wisely.

This system has, we believe, been
tried in other colleges and universities of the country with varying
degrees of success. It at least appears worthy of discussion. A cornmittee has been appointed at Lafayette to confer with the Dean and
faculty.

French Delegation
to Visit Hopkins
In the near future, Johns Hop_ kins will be visited by a delegation
representing the National Foundation for the Cite Universitaire of
Paris, which is touring this country
in order to inspect the student unions at leading American universities preparatory to drawing up plans
for the projected union in Paris.
This.group is scheduled to visit
Princeton, Yale, the University of
Toronto, the University of Michigan, the University of Chicago, the
University of California, Columbia,
Johns Hopkins and other universities.
Those in the delegation are Senator Andre Honorat, formerly Minister of Public Instruction, and President of the Foundation; Lucien
Bechman, its architect, and Augusti
Declos, Associate Director of the
National office of French Universities . They expect to return to
France on December 27, and as
soon thereafter as plans can be
drawn up and approved the construction of the student union will
be begun.

Two Englishmen To
Lecture This Week
During this week two Englishmen will give public lectures in the
Civil Engineering Building. This
afternoon at five o'clock, Mr. Noel
E. O'Dell will give an illustrated
talk on the Mount Everest Expedition. On Thursday afternoon, at
the same hour, Philip Henry Kerr
will speak on "Problems of the
British Empire."
Mr. O'Dell was a member of the
Mount Everest Expedition, returning as a hero, because of his gallant ascent of the mountain to rescue two companions.
Mr. Kerr has taken an active
part in British politics, holding
the secretaryship to the Prime Minister during the World War.

Freshman hopes of making a
Clean sweep in all lower class competitions were dashed to the ground
.when a belated rally late in the
fourth quarter ended in a fumble on
the Sophs' 10-yard line. Previous
to this long march into the opposing territory, the Frosh had been
unable to gain little against the
heavier and more experienced line
of the Sophs.
First Half Even

The first half was characterized
by typically Frosh-Soph poor football. Little life was shown by either
team and no science whatsoever.
Whatever advantage there was lay
on the side of the Sophomores, who
Were able to make fewer fumbles,
and as a result a better showing.
For the entire first half the play
see-sawed back and forth around
the middle fo the field, neither team
having a capable attack to cope with
the strong defensive skill exhibited.
Frosh Fumble

The Frosh were particularly unfortunate in that they contintually
fumbled, Gibson, their only threat,
being especially guilty of this. A
long run around the end would get
Well underway and the white markers would be passing swiftly underfoot when a Soph would tackle and
the ball fly, only to be recovered
by the opposition. These fumbles
really cost the Frosh the game, for
Otherwise they outplayed their natural enemies and showed a far
greater knowledge of the game.
Sophs Lack Preparation

The lack of preparation for the
struggle was clearly -shown by the
Sophs, in their inability to throw
Passes or work in co-ordination in
any of their plays. The one high
spot of the game was the clean
tackling done by both teams, a very
unusual sight heretofore in the annual underclassmen's battles. Gump
for the Sophs was particularly effective in his defensive work.

Botanist to Lecture
On Central America
Using as his subject, "A Talk on
Central America," Mr. P. R. White,
who is pursuing a course in botany
at Johns Hopkins, will deliver an
address today.
The lecture, which will be supplemented by illustrations, will be
based on the lecturer's own experience. Mr. White, during the past
tWO years, has visited Cuba, Jamaica, Costa Rica and Panama.

PRICE 5 CENTS

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 6, 1927

CONTRACT LET FOR
WELCH LIBRARY
The contract for the erection of the William H Welch
Medical Library at the Johns
Hopkins Medical School has
been let to the Consolidated
Engineering Company, the
lowest bidder. It is expected
that, work will be begun immediately. Plans are being
made to have it completed
within ten months. The
structure itself will cost about
$397,000 and the total cost of
the building equipped will be
between $600,000 and $700,000.

TO REPLACE
SWIMMING AS WINTER SPORT

KELLY TO CAPTAIN
BASKETBALL
JAY HARRIERS

Wheeler, Track Star,
Patents Invention

Robert Kelly was elected captain of the 1928 Johns Hopkins
cross-country team at a meeting
held last Thursday night. Kelly
was opposed by Wheeler, but received a majority of votes for the
office.
• Kelly has been running very well
this season, placing close to Gwinn
and Schiebel in every race. He
placed third in the Maryland contest and showed well in the National
Junior A. A. U. meet on November
11. Kelly succeeds Herman Schiebel as captain of the Jay crosscountry squad.

Harold A. Wheeler, a graduate
student in the department of mathematics, has recently invented and
patented an automatic volume control for radio receivers that will
eliminate to some extent the fading
of distant stations.
The inventor of this device
claims that if incorporated in the
amplifying section of a receiver,
the operator will be enabled to tune
in on station after station without
any change in volume.
He said that the carrier wave of
the station is amplified and then rectified, the wave being used to control volume by applying a varying
negative voltage to the grid of the
adio frequency amplifier.
Wheeler is better known to Hopkins students as a member of the
cross-country team, which has just
closed one of the most successful
seasons in the history of Hopkins
track, and for his sterling work in
the half-mile on last spring's squad.

Hopkins will enter a team in the
South Atlantic Amateur Athletic
Union meet to be held on December 17 at Clifton Park. Gwinn,
Schiebel and Kelly will run for
Hopkins and four other men will be
picked from Wheeler, Emerson,
Water,_Rosser, Yellott, Miller and
Onorato to enter with them.
The course will be the same as
that traversed by the Blue Jays in
the National Junior A. A. U. meet
held on November 11. The course
is two miles long and will be covered three times by the contestants.
The starting and finishing line will
be the Mansion House in Clifton
Park.
The Emorywood Athletic Club
has already signified its intention of
entering the race and this will proyide another opportunity for a meeting between Bill Agee and Dick
Gwinn. Agee has beaten Gwinn
twice by a small margin and this
meet will give the Hopkins runner
an attempt to avenge these defeats.

ENGINEERS' DANCE
SATURDAY NIGHT
This Saturday evening, December 10, the annual Engineers' dance will be held in the
C. E. Hall. Though given by
the members of the Engineering School, the whole student
body is invited, and it is hoped
that a large crowd will turn
out.
The admission will be one
dollar stag or couple; tickets
may be obtained from the
committee — John Mathews,
John Eldridge and Ferd Kaufholz.

FROSH AND SOPHS TOSS PAINT
BUT RUSH ENDS IN USUAL!TIE
The usual draw concluded what
was literally one of the most colorful gatherings of the season. Purnell Hall's sophomores and Martin
Eliot's frosh had at each other Saturday afternoon in the accepted
manner, with innovations. The
innovations in this year's class rush
were, of course, the substitution of
one period for two, and of freeflowing red and green paint for a
torn flag mounted by a boy.
This departure from former practice was intended to end the hopeless series of ties in which the rushes
have frequently finished, but its
purpose seems not 'to have been
carried. Any attempt to assign a
name to the color of the pole at the
end of the fray would have been
overly. ambitious, and Judge Blandi
perforce followed the only course
open to him in pronouncing the result a draw.
The pep meeting of the freshmen was a complete failure as such,
but it served to assemble the vanguard of thirty-one's rough-clad
warriors, who laid plans for distressing the poor sophs.
Many outsiders were among the
rather large crowd which gathered
on the hill at the east end of the
main field and below on the edge of
the practice field. The cold, brisk
weather put a snap in the spectators
and made them wish for action.
The gallery was largely composed
of upperclassmen, some "dragging,"
but mostly alone. The ultra-collegiate element was represented by
the sprinkling of canes and fur

TAU BETA P110 INITIATE FIVE MEN
Dean Whitehead of Engineering
School to be Principal
Speaker at Assembly
Four seniors and one junior will
be initiated into Tau Beta Pi, honorary engineering fraternity, at this
Thursday's assembly. Dean Whitehead of the Engineering School,
who has recently returned from his
tour of Europe as Exchange Professor to France, will be the speaker of the occasion. He will comment on his trip.
Initiations into Tau Beta Pi are
held twice each year, in the spring
and fall. In the fall the upperquarter of the senior class and three
of the upper eight of the junior
class are eligible for election. In
the spring only the upper eight of
the junior class are eligible. Scholarship is the primary requirement
to admission, but other qualifications are also taken into consideration. Tau Beta Pi is rated a5 high
in engineering circles as is Phi Beta
Kappa for academic scholarship.
The names of the five new Hopkins
initiates are being withheld until
the assembly.

BOOKS

TWO YEARS OR FOUR
An interesting sequel to Mr. George H. Palmer's polemic
against the junior college in last April's Atlantic Monthly appears
in the current number of the Atlantic. Mr. Palmer's arguments
are based upon two assumptions: that the American colleges are
instrumental in creating a class of men whom we might term
the "gifted amateur," and that "in life everywhere it is the 'over
and above' that counts."
The junior college should not be regarded, it seems to us, as a
sort of preparatory school for two more years of cultural education. If its function were this, it would be an undeniable
anomaly. If a man feels that he needs or wants four years of
cultural preparation, he should attend a college for four years,
but should not take two years at a junior college and then two
more at a college.
The problem, however, is not, as Mr. Palmer says, the segregation of the "competent" from the "incompetent" by sending the
latter to junior college, but a determination, if possible, of whether
or not the great majority of men who do spend four years at
college would not have done just as well if they had attended only
two years. Palmer continues to say that the only fit judges of
who are "competent" and who are not are the candidates themselves. This is only partially true, for the real test of whether
or not a college education has been a benefit comes after a man
has been out of college for four or five years. It is only then
that he can tell whether his "liberal education" has opened to him
new channels of thought, new channels of reading, and newer
interests in life which would have remained closed to him had
he not attended college.
Though thefe is, of course, no definite proof of the value of a
four-year course as opposed to a two-year course, we are inclined
to believe that the very great majority of college men's lives would
be practically the same had they received two years of collegiate
education or four. The "gifted amateur," if he be truly gifted,
will interest himself in his hobby just as much after two years
as he would after four. There may be a few exceptions, but they
are not in the majority. And those men in whom their college
years have not excited additional intellectual curiosity certainly
gain nothing from the additional two years.
In advocating the junior college, we assume that it should be
conducted along collegiate, and not prep school lines. It would
then fulfill the needs of the very great majority of men who are
now spending four years in getting a "background" which they
could obtain in less. And those men who really, sincerely feel
that they want more than merely a background can study for
higher degrees.

FIGURES IN RELIGIOUS CENSUS INDICATE
LIBERALITY IN RELIGOUS THOUGHT
Figures of the annual religious
census, taken among the undergraduates by the campus Young Men's
Christian Association, show a
marked increase in the number of
men who declare no preference for
any particular church denomination.
Of a total of 770 students represented in the census, 144, or a little
les sthan 19 per cent., show no preference. Last year's percentage of
these students was about 14 per
cent., while reports of previous years
also show a steady upward increase.
Commenting,upon this phase of
the census results, E. A. Schaal,
intercollegiate secretary of the Hopkins "Y," expressed the opinion that
the facts show a tendency toward
liberality in religious thought.
"It may be," Mr. Schaal said,
"that the increase is a reflection of
the public attitude, toward the
church. For I believe that college
students are a representative crosssection of the community.
Attitude Shifting

"Apparently, the public attitude
is shifting—becoming negative with
regard to religious matters. There
is in progress a revolt against the

Apparently George had that inJ. L. S.
definable something which made
him irresistible to sex starved women. It is estimated that he had
affairs with at least thirty and probably many more women. Of this
number he married about twentyone. However, George was never
arrested for polygamy. In fact,
after deserting and robbing his girl
friends, he was still their ideal and
was welcome to return to them
whenever he chose. George was
far from being handsome, as could
be readily determined from a picture which Dr. Oliver exhibited to
the residents.
For a while he was happy and
contented with merely leaving after
one of his honeymoons with his
wife's clothes and ready cash, but
having mastered this game he became ambitious and desired to do
bigger and better things. In order
to obtain the entire estate of his
wife, he found that it would be
necessary to have her sign it over
to him and then dispose of her.
After treating his new wife to an
enjoyable honeymoon and having
her sign her estate over to him,
George suggested that she take a
bath. During the bath he grabbed
her by a leg with one hand and
shoved her head down with the
other. A few tears and George took
over the estate. Finally, one of
his father-in-laws checked up on
him and one beautiful day they attached a rope to his neck.
Many interesting and curious details were brought out during his
trial, which lasted twenty-four days.
It was a subject of much interest
as to the cause of George's strange
influence over women. Furthermore, the technique of the murder
itself was carefully studied and
enacted in the court. Few criminals
are original, but George contributed
a novel method of disposal to the
criminal records.
The trial brought out that even
George had several admirable traits.
In spite of his many affaires du
caeur, he remained faithful to one
woman to whom he always returned
after one of his exploits. He gave
her some of the clothes that he had
robbed from his wives. He posed
as an antique collector and explained his sudden wealth by a,fortunate sale of some piece of pottery
or the like. Furthermore, George
always showed his wives a good
time before he murdered them. Divorce never bothered George.
In closing, Dr. Oliver expressed
the wish that no resident possesses

nitely- chosen and if anyone feels

first practice to show her ability.
This is the golden opportunity for
our women—will they show enough
interest in the movement to bring
it to a successful completion, or
will they let others usurp the place
in sports that is rightfully ours?
The decision is for them to make—
may they choose wisely.

French Delegation
to Visit Hopkins
In the near future, Johns Hop_ kins will be visited by a delegation
representing the National Foundation for the Cite Universitaire of
Paris, which is touring this country
in order to inspect the student unions at leading American universities preparatory to drawing up plans
for the projected union in Paris.
This.group is scheduled to visit
Princeton, Yale, the University of
Toronto, the University of Michigan, the University of Chicago, the
University of California, Columbia,
Johns Hopkins and other universities.
Those in the delegation are Senator Andre Honorat, formerly Minister of Public Instruction, and President of the Foundation; Lucien
Bechman, its architect, and Augusti
Declos, Associate Director of the
National office of French Universities . They expect to return to
France on December 27, and as
soon thereafter as plans can be
drawn up and approved the construction of the student union will
be begun.

Two Englishmen To
Lecture This Week
During this week two Englishmen will give public lectures in the
Civil Engineering Building. This
afternoon at five o'clock, Mr. Noel
E. O'Dell will give an illustrated
talk on the Mount Everest Expedition. On Thursday afternoon, at
the same hour, Philip Henry Kerr
will speak on "Problems of the
British Empire."
Mr. O'Dell was a member of the
Mount Everest Expedition, returning as a hero, because of his gallant ascent of the mountain to rescue two companions.
Mr. Kerr has taken an active
part in British politics, holding
the secretaryship to the Prime Minister during the World War.
